TopicTitle: How do ducted fans work?(how do you calculate thrust?)

Articles.Content:
I'm trying to follow the calcualtions given in this thread on stack exchange I can't figure out how he got his answer.

https://aviation.stackexchange.com/a/16550

He says it's 4kg of thrust but I can't figure out the other stuff.

Ct*p*area*tip^2

0.03*1.225*?*0.6=4kg?!

 

Edited April 25 by Arugela

Area is the area of the ducted fan in m^2. who is pi*r^2 =0,0177 m^2 with an 15 cm fan 
but plugging that into the formula gives 0,000389  tip speed should be 0.6^2 who give an even lower value 0,000234 so something is wrong here

0,6M I presume is 0,6 Mach, but I'd expect m/s to be the expected unit, which gives us 24,75, so we're at least in the ballpark.

Also, he just might have borked the math.

Edited April 25 by Shpaget

ducted fans are well tuned systems which can be well optimized. but that optimization usually comes at the cost of a vary narrow operational envelope. laminar flow wings have a similar problem. fan design in general is a deceptively complex problem.

Edited April 25 by Nuke
